moves.1. b4: The preferred computer line for black is 1... d5 2. Nf3 Nf6 3. e3 Bf5 4. Nc3 e6 5. a3 a5 6. b5 Bd6 7. Be2 c5
moves.1... c5: White should play 2. bxc5 e5 (2... e6 3. d4) 3. e3 Bxc5 4. Nf3 d6 5. d4 which gives him a slight advantage.
moves.4. c3 e5 5. cxd4 cxd4 6. Nf3 Bd6 7. e3 N: 10. Na3 with the intent of Bc4, O-O, Re1, Bb3 and Nac4 was better.
moves.10... Be6: Instead the computer likes  10... Nbd7 followed by Qe7.
moves.11. Bc4: Best for black is 11... Bxe5 12. dxe5 Nfd7 13. O-O (13. Bxe6 Nc5 14. Bxf7+ Rxf7  is winning for black.) 13... Nc5
moves.11... Bxc4 12. Qxc4: 12. Nxc4 instead gives white a slight advantage.
moves.12... Nbd7:
Instead 12. Nxc4 gives white a slight advantage.
Here 13. O-O is necessary to get the king out of the line of fire, because Black can play dxe5 followed by Nc5 and Nd3+.  So 13. O-O Rc8 14. Qb3 Bxe5 15. dxe5 Nc5 16. Qg3 is equal.
moves.13. Qb3: Now black is winning with 13... Bxe5 14. dxe5 Nc5, which according to the computer, gives black has a huge advantage.  However, understanding why this is winning is not easy.  This leads to many complicated lines linked to below.
moves.13... Qc7: Although this looks like a reasonable move, the previously stated 13... Bxe5 14. dxe5 Nc5 is much better.
moves.14... Nxe5 15. dxe5 Bxe5 16. Bxe5 Qxe5 1: 17. Na3 is a little better so as to later be able to go to c4, and to meet black's Ng4 with Qg3.
moves.17... Rfd8:
17. ... Ng4 first is also good.

Here white could play 18. Qd1 to stop Ng4.
moves.18. Rad1: Now Black is winning with 18... Ng4 19. g3 Qh5 20. h4 Ne5 which leads to a ton of complicated variations linked to below.
moves.18... Rd3:
Although I was proud of this move, it misses the much better and very complicated Ng4.

Now 19. h3 is necessary to stop Ng4.
moves.19. Rfe1: Black can still win with 19... Ng4 which also leads to some complicated lines linked below.
